<line: 24> )  Magistrate Judge Cox

<line: 26> )

<line: 28> )
<line: 29> Defendants  
<line: 30> )  

[TITLE]
<line: 32> DEFENDANT PETER DIANGI'S, ANSWER TO PLAINTIFFS' AMENDED
<line: 33> COMPLAINT AT LAW

[TEXT]
<line: 35> NOW COMES the defendant, PETER DIANGI, by and through his attorneys, 
<line: 36> LITCHFIELD CAVO LLP and for his answer to plaintiffs’ Amended Complaint at Law, states 
<line: 37> as follow: 

[TITLE]
<line: 39> COMMON FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS

[TEXT]
<line: 41> 1. 
<line: 42> At all times relevant herein, the Plaintiffs, ANDREW TERRELL and GEORGE 
<line: 43> TERRELL were residents of the County of Cook and State of Illinois. 

[TEXT]
<line: 45> ANSWER: Defendant admits the allegations contained in paragraph one. 

[TEXT]
<line: 47> 2. 
<line: 48> At all times relevant herein, the Defendant, PETER DIANGI was a resident of 
<line: 49> County of Cook and State of Illinois. 

[TEXT]
<line: 51> ANSWER: Defendant admits the allegations contained in paragraph two. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 53> -1-

[TITLE]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 31      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 2 of 40

[TEXT]
<line: 4> 3. 
<line: 5> At all times relevant herein, the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, was employed by 
<line: 6> the Defendant, SILVER LAKE, as a security guard. 

[TEXT]
<line: 8> ANSWER: Defendant admits the allegations contained in paragraph three. 

[TEXT]
<line: 10> 4. 
<line: 11> At all times relevant herein, the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, was employed by 
<line: 12> the Defendant, Orland Park, as a police officer. 

[TEXT]
<line: 14> ANSWER: Defendant admits the allegations contained in paragraph four. 

[TEXT]
<line: 16> 5. 
<line: 17> At all times relevant herein, the Defendant, SILVER LAKE, was a duly licensed 
<line: 18> corporation, incorporated in the State of Illinois and doing business as Silver Lake Country Club 
<line: 19> and located at 14700 South 82nd Avenue in the City of Orland Park, County of Cook, and State 
<line: 20> of Illinois. 

[TEXT]
<line: 22> ANSWER: Defendant admits the allegations contained in paragraph five. 

[TEXT]
<line: 24> 6. 
<line: 25> On or about March 18, 2006, the Plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL, and his 
<line: 26> fiancée were married at Queen of Martyrs Church in Evergreen Park. Immediately after the 
<line: 27> wedding ceremony, the Plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL, his fiancée, and various other members 
<line: 28> of the wedding guests, including the Plaintiff GEORGE TERRELL, attended a wedding 
<line: 29> reception at Silver Lake Country Club. 

[TEXT]
<line: 31> ANSWER: Defendant neither admits nor denies the allegations contained in paragraph six, but 
<line: 32> demands strict proof thereof. 

[TEXT]
<line: 34> 7. 
<line: 35> The Defendant, PETER DIANGI, grabbed the Plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL, 
<line: 36> by the arm. 

[TEXT]
<line: 38> ANSWER: Defendant admits the allegations contained in paragraph seven. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 40> -2-

[TITLE]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 31      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 3 of 40

[TEXT]
<line: 4> 8. 
<line: 5> Prior to Grabbing the Plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL, the Defendant, PETER 
<line: 6> DIANGI, did not identify himself as a security guard or other employee of Silver Lake, nor did 
<line: 7> he identify himself as a police officer. 

[TEXT]
<line: 9> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph eight. 

[TEXT]
<line: 11> 9. 
<line: 12> Subsequent to grabbing the Plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL, the Defendant, 
<line: 13> PETER DIANGI, grabbed ANDREW Terrell by the neck. A melee ensued as wedding guests 
<line: 14> attempted to defend the Plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL. 

[TEXT]
<line: 16> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph nine. 

[TEXT]
<line: 18> 10. 
<line: 19> At all times, the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, was dressed in "plain clothes", and 
<line: 20> was not wearing a police uniform. 

[TEXT]
<line: 22> ANSWER: Defendant admits the allegations contained in paragraph ten. 

[TEXT]
<line: 24> 11. 
<line: 25> As a result of the aforestated melee, the Plaintiffs, ANDREW TERRELL and 
<line: 26> GEORGE TERRELL, were arrested and charged with battery. 

[TEXT]
<line: 28> ANSWER: Defendant admits the allegations contained in paragraph eleven. 

[TEXT]
<line: 30> 12. 
<line: 31> The arrests of the Plaintiffs were made under false pretenses, given that the 
<line: 32> Defendant, PETER DIANGI, justigated the events leading to the aforesaid arrests.  

[TEXT]
<line: 34> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph twelve. 

[TEXT]
<line: 36> 13. 
<line: 37> The Defendant, PETER DIANGI, engaged in conduct against the plaintiffs, 
<line: 38> which conduct included striking the plaintiffs, grabbing the plaintiffs and spraying with pepper 
<line: 39> spray.  

[TEXT]
<line: 41> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph thirteen. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 43> -3-

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 31      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 4 of 40

[TITLE]
<line: 4> COUNT I-BATTERY

[TITLE]
<line: 6> (Andrew Terrell v. Peter Diangi)

[TEXT]
<line: 8> 1. through 13. Plaintiff adopts and realleges Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of the COMMON 
<line: 9> FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS section as and for Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of Count I, as though 
<line: 10> fully set forth herein and incorporate the same by reference. 

[TEXT]
<line: 12> ANSWER: Defendant re-adopts and re-alleges in answers to paragraphs 1 through 13, inclusive 
<line: 13> of the common factual allegations section as it answers to paragraph 1 through 13 of Count I, as 
<line: 14> fully set forth herein and incorporated by referenced. 

[TEXT]
<line: 16> 14. 
<line: 17> The conduct and force used by PETER DIANGI toward the Plaintiff, ANDREW 
<line: 18> TERRELL, was intentional, malicious, excessive and in reckless disregard of the Plaintiffs' 
<line: 19> constitutional rights. Moreover, the use of force used against the Plaintiff was excessive.  

[TEXT]
<line: 21> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph fourteen. 

[TEXT]
<line: 23> 15. 
<line: 24> As a result of the aforementioned conduct of the Defendants, the Plaintiff 
<line: 25> suffered serious physical injuries. Plaintiff also incurred medical expenses and other damages, 
<line: 26> including physical and emotional pain and suffering. 

[TEXT]
<line: 28> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph fifteen. 

[TEXT]
<line: 30> 16. 
<line: 31> The Plaintiff's injuries were the proximate result of Defendant's aforementioned 
<line: 32> conduct. 

[TEXT]
<line: 34> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph sixteen. 

[TEXT]
<line: 36> WHEREFORE, the defendant, Peter DiAngi, denies that he is liable in any amount 
<line: 37> whatsoever, to plaintiff, Andrew Terrell, and demands judgment in his favor on all remaining 
<line: 38> pleadings. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 40> -4-

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 31      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 5 of 40

[TITLE]
<line: 4> COUNT II-ASSAULT

[TITLE]
<line: 6> (Andrew Terrell v. Peter Diangi)

[TEXT]
<line: 8> 1. through 13. Plaintiff adopts and realleges Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of the COMMON 
<line: 9> FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS section as and for Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of Count II, as though 
<line: 10> fully set forth herein and incorporate the same by reference.  

[TEXT]
<line: 12> ANSWER: Defendant re-adopts and re-alleges in answers to paragraphs 1 through 13, inclusive 
<line: 13> of the common factual allegations section as it answers to paragraph 1 through 13 of Count II, as 
<line: 14> fully set forth herein and incorporated by referenced. 

[TEXT]
<line: 16> 14. The Defendants' conduct placed Plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL in apprehension of 
<line: 17> immediate and imminent harm to his well being and safety, and he suffered great shame and 
<line: 18> humiliation and injury to his dignity and feelings, upsetting his mentally, emotionally and 
<line: 19> psychologically. 

[TEXT]
<line: 21> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph fourteen. 

[TEXT]
<line: 23> WHEREFORE, the defendant, Peter DiAngi, denies that he is liable in any amount 
<line: 24> whatsoever, to plaintiff, Andrew Terrell, and demands judgment in his favor on all remaining 
<line: 25> pleadings. 

[TITLE]
<line: 27> COUNT III – NEGLIGENCE

[TITLE]
<line: 29> (Andrew Terrell v. Peter Diangi)

[TEXT]
<line: 31> 1. 
<line: 32> At all times relevant herein, the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, was employed by 
<line: 33> the Defendant,  SILVER LAKE, as a security guard.  

[TEXT]
<line: 35> ANSWER: 
<line: 36> Defendant admits the allegations contained in paragraph one.  

[ABANDON]
<line: 38> -5-

[TITLE]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 31      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 6 of 40

[TEXT]
<line: 4> 2. 
<line: 5>  At all times relevant herein, the Defendant, SILVER LAKE, was a duly licensed 
<line: 6> corporation, incorporated in the State of Illinois and doing business as Silver Lake Country Club 
<line: 7> and located at 14700 South 82nd Avenue in the City of Orland Park, County of Cook, and State 
<line: 8> of Illinois. 

[TEXT]
<line: 10> ANSWER: 
<line: 11> Defendant admits the allegations contained in paragraph two.  

[TEXT]
<line: 13> 3. 
<line: 14> On or about March 18, 2006, the Plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL, and his 
<line: 15> fiancée were married at Queen of Martyrs Church in Evergreen Park. Immediately after the 
<line: 16> wedding ceremony, the plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL, his fiancée, and various other members 
<line: 17> of the wedding guests, including the Plaintiff GEORGE TERRELL, attended a wedding 
<line: 18> reception at Silver Lake Country Club. 

[TEXT]
<line: 20> ANSWER: 
<line: 21> Defendant admits the allegations contained in paragraph two.  

[TEXT]
<line: 23> 4. 
<line: 24> During the course of the reception, the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, was engaged 
<line: 25> in his ordinary duties as a security guard and was working in his capacity as employee or agent 
<line: 26> of the Defendant, SILVER LAKE. 

[TEXT]
<line: 28> ANSWER: 
<line: 29> Defendant adopts DiAngi’s answers to paragraph four as answered by attorney for 
<line: 30> Silver Lake.  

[TEXT]
<line: 32> 5. 
<line: 33> At all times relevant herein, the Defendant PETER DIANGI owed a duty of 
<line: 34> ordinary care to the Plaintiff while performing his tasks as a security officer. 

[TEXT]
<line: 36> ANSWER: 
<line: 37> Defendant adopts DiAngi’s answers to paragraph five as answered by attorney for 
<line: 38> Silver Lake.  

[TEXT]
<line: 40> 6. 
<line: 41> On March 18, 2006, the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, breached his aforesaid duty 
<line: 42> by engaging in one or more of the following negligent acts or omissions: 

[ABANDON]
<line: 44> -6-

[TITLE]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 31      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 7 of 40

[TEXT]
<line: 4> a. 
<line: 5> Negligently failed to identify himself as a security guard or employee of Silver 
<line: 6> Lake; 
<line: 7> b. 
<line: 8> Negligently pushed the Plaintiff; 
<line: 9> c. 
<line: 10> Negligently sprayed the Plaintiff with pepper spray; 
<line: 11> d. 
<line: 12> Negligently attempted to physically restrain the plaintiff; and/or 
<line: 13> e. 
<line: 14> Was otherwise negligent. 

[TEXT]
<line: 16> ANSWER: 
<line: 17> Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph six, including those 
<line: 18> allegations in sub-paragraphs (a) through (e), inclusive.  

[TEXT]
<line: 20> 7. As a result of the aforementioned conduct of the Defendants, the Plaintiff suffered 
<line: 21> serious physical injuries. Plaintiff also incurred medical expenses and other damages, including 
<line: 22> physical and emotional pain in and suffering. 

[TEXT]
<line: 24> ANSWER: 
<line: 25> Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph seven. 
<line: 26> 8. 
<line: 27> The Plaintiff's injuries were the proximate result of Defendant's aforementioned 
<line: 28> conduct. 

[TEXT]
<line: 30> ANSWER: 
<line: 31> Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph seven. 

[TEXT]
<line: 33> WHEREFORE, the defendant, Peter DiAngi, denies that he is liable in any amount 
<line: 34> whatsoever, to plaintiff, Andrew Terrell, and demands judgment in his favor on all remaining 
<line: 35> pleadings. 

[TITLE]

[TITLE]
<line: 39> (Andrew Terrell and Silver Lake)

[TEXT]

<line: 42> FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS section as and for Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of Count III, as

<line: 44> -7-

<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 31      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 8 of 40

[TEXT]
<line: 4> though fully set forth herein and incorporate the same by reference. 

[TEXT]
<line: 6> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count IV are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 7> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 9> 14. The conduct and force used by PETER DIANGI toward the Plaintiff, ANDREW 
<line: 10> TERRELL, was intentional, malicious and excessive and in reckless disregard of the Plaintiffs' 
<line: 11> constitutional rights. Moreover, the use of force used against the Plaintiff was excessive. 

[TEXT]
<line: 13> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count IV are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 14> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 16> 15. 
<line: 17> At all times relevant herein the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, was engaged in his 
<line: 18> ordinary duties as a security guard and employee, agent, apparent agent, and/or servant of the 
<line: 19> Defendant, SILVER LAKE. 

[TEXT]
<line: 21> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count IV are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 22> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 24> 16. 
<line: 25> At all times set forth in Paragraphs 1-13, PETER DIANGI knew that the 
<line: 26> Plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL, was legally on the premises of Silver Lake Country Club. 

[TEXT]
<line: 28> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count IV are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 29> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 31> 17. 
<line: 32> The Defendant's conduct in striking the Plaintiff and spraying the Plaintiff with 
<line: 33> mace was unjustified and excessive. 

[TEXT]
<line: 35> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count IV are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 36> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 38> -8-

[TITLE]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 31      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 9 of 40

[TEXT]
<line: 4> 18.

<line: 6> suffered serious injuries. Plaintiff also incurred medical expenses and other damages, including 
<line: 7> physical and emotional pain and suffering. 

[TEXT]
<line: 9> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count IV are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 10> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 12> 19. 
<line: 13> The Plaintiff's injuries were the proximate result of Defendant's aforementioned 
<line: 14> conduct. 

[TEXT]
<line: 16> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count IV are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 17> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 19> 20. 
<line: 20> The Defendant, SILVER LAKE, is vicariously liable for the actions and conduct 
<line: 21> of PETER DIANGI. 

[TEXT]
<line: 23> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count IV are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 24> defendant makes no answer to same

[TEXT]

[TITLE]
<line: 8> COUNT VI – NEGLIGENCE

[TITLE]
<line: 10> (Andrew Terrell v. Silver Lake)

[TEXT]
<line: 12> 1. 
<line: 13> At all times relevant herein, the Defendant, SILVER LAKE, was a duly licensed 
<line: 14> corporation, incorporated in the State of Illinois and doing business as Silver Lake Country Club 
<line: 15> and located at 14700 South 82"d Avenue in the City of Orland Park, County of Cook, and State 
<line: 16> of Illinois. 

[TEXT]
<line: 18> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count VI are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 19> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 21> 2. 
<line: 22> Prior to March 18, 2006, the Defendant, SILVER LAKE, hired and employed the 
<line: 23> Defendant, PETER DIANGI, as a security guard at the Silver Lake Country Club.  

[TEXT]
<line: 25> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count VI are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 26> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 28> 3. 
<line: 29>  On or about March 18, 2006, the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, was working as a 
<line: 30> security guard and performing his ordinary duties as an employee or agent of the Defendant, 
<line: 31> SILVER LAKE. 

[TEXT]
<line: 33> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count VI are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 34> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 36> 4. 
<line: 37>  On or about March 18, 2006, the Plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL, and his fiancée 
<line: 38> were married at Queen of Martyrs Church in Evergreen Park. Immediately after the wedding 
<line: 39> ceremony, the plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL, his fiancée, and various other members of the  

[ABANDON]
<line: 41> -10-

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 31      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 11 of 40

[TEXT]
<line: 4> wedding guests, including the Plaintiff GEORGE TERRELL, attended a wedding reception at 
<line: 5> Silver Lake Country Club. 

[TEXT]
<line: 7> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count VI are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 8> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 10> 5.
<line: 11> During the course of the reception, the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, was engaged 
<line: 12> in his ordinary duties as a security guard and was working in his capacity as employee or agent 
<line: 13> of the Defendant, SILVER LAKE. 

[TEXT]
<line: 15> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count VI are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 16> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 18> 6. 
<line: 19> At all times relevant herein, the Defendant SILVER LAKE, through its 
<line: 20> employees and agents, including PETER DIANGI, owed a duty of ordinary care to the Plaintiff 
<line: 21> to hire well-qualified security personnel, and to ensure that the security acted appropriately 
<line: 22> providing security. 

[TEXT]
<line: 24> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count VI are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 25> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 27> 7. 
<line: 28> On March 18, 2006, the Defendant, SILVER LAKE, through its employees 
<line: 29> and/or agents, including the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, breached his aforesaid duties to the 
<line: 30> Plaintiff by engaging in one or more of the following negligent acts or omissions: 

[TEXT]
<line: 32> a. 
<line: 33> Negligently failed to properly train the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, as a 
<line: 34> security guard responsible for providing security to patron during social 
<line: 35> events at SILVER LAKE; 
<line: 36> b. 
<line: 37> Negligently failed to adequately supervise the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, 
<line: 38> during the performance of his duties as a security guard; 
<line: 39> c. 
<line: 40> Negligently permitted the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, to work as a 
<line: 41> security guard without sufficient assistance or supervision; 

[ABANDON]
<line: 43> -11-

[TITLE]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 31      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 12 of 40

[TEXT]
<line: 4> d. 
<line: 5> Negligently failed to provide adequate security personnel to assist the 
<line: 6> Defendant, PETER DIANGI, in providing security; 
<line: 7> e. 
<line: 8> Negligently hired the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, as a security officer.  

[TEXT]
<line: 10> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count VI are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 11> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 13> 8. 
<line: 14> In addition to the aforesaid negligent acts and/or omissions, the Defendant, J 
<line: 15> SILVER LAKE, is vicariously liable for the negligent acts and/or omissions, the Defendant, 
<line: 16> PETER DIANGI, as alleged in Count III above. 

[TEXT]
<line: 18> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count VI are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 19> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 21> 9. 
<line: 22> As a result of the aforementioned conduct of the Defendants, the Plaintiff 
<line: 23> suffered serious physical injuries. Plaintiff also incurred medical expenses and other damages, 
<line: 24> including physical and emotional pain and suffering. 

[TEXT]
<line: 26> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count VI are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 27> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 29> 10. 
<line: 30> The Plaintiff's injuries were the proximate result of Defendant's aforementioned 
<line: 31> conduct. 

[TEXT]
<line: 33> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count VI are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 34> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TITLE]
<line: 36> COUNT VII-BATTERY

[TITLE]
<line: 38> (Andrew Terrell v. Orland Park)

[TEXT]
<line: 40> 1. through 13. Plaintiff adopts and realleges Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of the COMMON 
<line: 41> FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS section as and for Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of Count V, as though

[TEXT]
<line: 4> fully set forth herein and incorporate the same by reference. 

[TEXT]
<line: 6> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count VII are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 7> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 9> 14. 
<line: 10> The conduct and force used by PETER DIANGI as stated herein was intentional, 
<line: 11> malicious, excessive and in reckless disregard of the Plaintiffs' constitutional rights. Moreover, 
<line: 12> the use of force used against the Plaintiff was excessive. 

[TEXT]
<line: 14> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count VII are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 15> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 17> 15. 
<line: 18> As a result of the aforementioned conduct of the Defendants, the Plaintiff 
<line: 19> suffered serious injuries. Plaintiff also incurred medical expenses and other damages, including 
<line: 20> physical and emotional pain and suffering. 

[TEXT]
<line: 22> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count VII are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 23> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 25> 16. 
<line: 26> The Plaintiff's injuries were the proximate result of Defendant's aforementioned 
<line: 27> conduct. 

[TEXT]
<line: 29> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count VII are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 30> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 32> 17. 
<line: 33> The Defendant, ORLAND PARK, is vicariously liable for the actionable conduct 
<line: 34> of its employees, agents, and/or servants including PETER DIANGI. 

[TEXT]
<line: 36> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count VII are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 37> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 39> -13-

[ABANDON]

[TITLE]
<line: 4> COUNT VIII-ASSAULT

[TITLE]
<line: 6> (Andrew Terrell v. Orland Park)

[TEXT]
<line: 8> 1. through 13. Plaintiff adopts and realleges Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of the COMMON 
<line: 9> FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS section as and for Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of Count VI, as 
<line: 10> though fully set forth herein and incorporate the same by reference. 

[TEXT]
<line: 12> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count VIII are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 13> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 15>  14. The conduct of Defendant, ORLAND PARK, by and through its employee and/or 
<line: 16> agent, PETER DIANGI, placed Plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL, in apprehension of immediate 
<line: 17> and imminent harm to his well being and safety, and he suffered great shame and humiliation 
<line: 18> and injury to his dignity and feelings, upsetting them mentally, emotionally and psychologically. 

[TEXT]
<line: 20> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count VIII are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 21> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TITLE]
<line: 23> COUNT IX-WILLFUL & WANTON

[TITLE]
<line: 25> (Andrew Terrell v. Peter Diangi)

[TEXT]
<line: 27> 1. through 13. Plaintiff adopts and realleges Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of the COMMON 
<line: 28> FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS section as and for Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of Count VII, as 
<line: 29> though fully set forth herein and incorporate the same by reference. 

[TEXT]
<line: 31> ANSWER: Defendant re-adopts and re-alleges in answers to paragraphs 1 through 13, inclusive 
<line: 32> of the common factual allegations section as it answers to paragraph 1 through 13 of Count IX, 
<line: 33> as fully set forth herein and incorporated by referenced. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 35> -14-

[TITLE]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 31      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 15 of 40

[TEXT]
<line: 4> 14. 
<line: 5> Pursuant to 745 ILCS 10/2-202, police officers are liable for injuries resulting 
<line: 6> from their willful and wanton acts or omissions while engaged in the execution or enforcement 
<line: 7> of the law. 

[TEXT]
<line: 9> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph fourteen. 

[TEXT]
<line: 11> 15. 
<line: 12> At all time set forth in Paragraphs 1-13, PETER DIANGI, knew that the Plaintiff, 
<line: 13> ANDREW TERRELL, was legally upon the premises of Silver Lake Country Club.  

[TEXT]
<line: 15> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph sixteen. 

[TEXT]
<line: 17> 16. 
<line: 18> At all time set forth in Paragraphs 1-13, PETER DIANGI was engaged in the 
<line: 19> execution or enforcement of the law when he grabbed and/or struck the Plaintiff, ANDREW 
<line: 20> TERRELL. More over, Officer METELSKI engaged in willful and wanton conduct during said 
<line: 21> execution or enforcement of the law by using excessive force in attempting to arrest ANDREW 
<line: 22> TERRELL. 

[TEXT]
<line: 24> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph sixteen. 

[TEXT]
<line: 26> 17. 
<line: 27> As a result of the aforementioned conduct of the Defendants, the Plaintiff 
<line: 28> suffered serious injuries. Plaintiff also incurred medical expenses and other damages, including 
<line: 29> physical and emotional pain and suffering. 

[TEXT]
<line: 31> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph seventeen. 

[TEXT]
<line: 33> 18. 
<line: 34> The Plaintiff's injuries were the proximate result of Defendant's aforementioned 
<line: 35> conduct. 

[TEXT]
<line: 37> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph eighteen. 

[TEXT]
<line: 39> WHEREFORE, the defendant, Peter DiAngi, denies that he is liable in any amount 
<line: 40> whatsoever, to plaintiff, Andrew Terrell, and demands judgment in his favor on all remaining 
<line: 41> pleadings.

<line: 35> ANDREW TERRELL.

<line: 11> 15.

<line: 13> deliberate indifference to the Plaintiffs rights under the Constitution. 

[TEXT]

[TEXT]
<line: 17> 16. 
<line: 18> The conduct of the Defendants deprived the Plaintiff of the following rights, 
<line: 19> privileges, and immunities secured to him by the Constitution of the United States. 

[TEXT]
<line: 21> a. 
<line: 22> The right of the Plaintiff to be secure in his person and effects against 
<line: 23> unreasonable search and seizure under the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to 
<line: 24> the Constitution of the United States (Art. IV, U.S. Constitution, Art. XIV, U.S. 
<line: 25> Constitution.); and 
<line: 26> b. 
<line: 27> The right of the Plaintiff not to be deprived of life, liberty, or property without 
<line: 28> due process of law, and the right to the equal protection of the laws, secured by 
<line: 29> the Fourteenth Amendment of the Constitution of the United States (Art. XIV, 
<line: 30> U.S. Constitution). 

[TEXT]
<line: 32> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph sixteen, including those 
<line: 33> sub-paragraphs (a) and (b), inclusive 

[TEXT]
<line: 35> 17.

<line: 37> its officers, including, but not limited to PETER DIANGI, regarding proper procedure to be used 
<line: 38> in apprehending a suspect, including the proper use of force. 

[TEXT]
<line: 40> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph seventeen. 

[TEXT]
<line: 42> 18.

<line: 44> officers, including, but not limited to PETER DIANGI, following excessive use of force by 

[ABANDON]
<line: 46> -18-

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 31      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 19 of 40

[TEXT]
<line: 4> police such that its officers, including, but not limited to PETER DIANGI, were led to believe 
<line: 5> that the consequences of failing to follow proper procedure in the exercise of force were minimal 
<line: 6> or nonexistent. 

[TEXT]
<line: 8> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph eighteen. 

[TEXT]
<line: 10> 19. 
<line: 11> As a result of the failure of ORLAND PARK to properly train, supervise and 
<line: 12> discipline its officers, including, but not limited to PETER DIANGI, the Plaintiff suffered 
<line: 13> serious injuries. Plaintiff also incurred medical expenses and other damages, including physical 
<line: 14> and emotional pain and suffering. 

[TEXT]
<line: 16> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph nineteen. 

[TEXT]
<line: 18> 20.

<line: 20> conduct. 

[TEXT]

<line: 25> whatsoever, to plaintiff, Andrew Terrell, and demands judgment in his favor on all remaining

[TITLE]
<line: 16> COUNT XIV-NEGLIGENCE

[TITLE]
<line: 18> (George Terrell v. Peter Diangi)

[TEXT]
<line: 20> 1. 
<line: 21> At all times relevant herein, the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, was employed by 
<line: 22> the Defendant, SILVER LAKE, as a security guard. 

[TEXT]
<line: 24> ANSWER: Defendant admit the allegations set forth in paragraph one.  

[TEXT]
<line: 26> 2. 
<line: 27>  At all times relevant herein, the Defendant, SILVER LAKE, was a duly licensed 
<line: 28> corporation, incorporated in the State of Illinois and doing business as Silver Lake Country Club 
<line: 29> and located at 14700 South 82nd Avenue in the City of Orland Park, County of Cook, and State 
<line: 30> of Illinois. 

[TEXT]
<line: 32> ANSWER: Defendant admit the allegations set forth in paragraph two.  

[TEXT]
<line: 34> 3. 
<line: 35> On or about March 18, 2006, the Plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL, and his fiancée 
<line: 36> were married at Queen of Martyrs Church in Evergreen Park. Immediately after the wedding 
<line: 37> ceremony, the plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL, his fiancée, and various other members of the  

[ABANDON]
<line: 39> -21-

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 31      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 22 of 40

[TEXT]
<line: 4> wedding guests, including the Plaintiff GEORGE TERRELL, attended a wedding reception at 
<line: 5> Silver Lake Country Club. 

[TEXT]
<line: 7> ANSWER: Defendant neither admits nor denies the allegations contained in paragraph three, but 
<line: 8> demands strict proof thereof. 

[TEXT]
<line: 10> 4.
<line: 11> During the course of the reception, the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, was engaged 
<line: 12> in his ordinary duties as a security guard and was working in his capacity as employee or agent 
<line: 13> of the Defendant, SILVER LAKE. 

[TEXT]
<line: 15> ANSWER:  Defendant admit the allegations set forth in paragraph four. 

[TEXT]
<line: 17> 5. 
<line: 18> At all times relevant herein, the Defendant PETER DIANGI owed a duty of 
<line: 19> ordinary care to the Plaintiff while performing his tasks as a security officer. 

[TEXT]
<line: 21> ANSWER: Defendant admit the allegations set forth in paragraph five.  

[TEXT]
<line: 23> 6. 
<line: 24> On March 18, 2006, the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, breached his aforesaid duty 
<line: 25> by engaging in one or more of the following negligent acts or omissions: 

[TEXT]
<line: 27> a. 
<line: 28> Negligently failed to identify himself as a security guard or employee of Silver 
<line: 29> Lake; 
<line: 30> b. 
<line: 31> Negligently pushed the Plaintiff; 
<line: 32> c. 
<line: 33> Negligently sprayed the Plaintiff with pepper spray; 
<line: 34> d. 
<line: 35> Negligently attempted to physically restrain the plaintiff; and/or 
<line: 36> e. 
<line: 37> Was otherwise negligent.  

[TEXT]
<line: 39> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations set forth in paragraph  six.  

[TEXT]
<line: 41> 7.

<line: 43> serious physical injuries. Plaintiff also incurred medical expenses and other damages, including 

[ABANDON]
<line: 45> -22-

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 31      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 23 of 40

[TEXT]
<line: 4> physical and emotional pain and suffering. 

[TEXT]
<line: 6> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations set forth in paragraph  seven.  

[TEXT]
<line: 8> 8.

<line: 10> conduct. 

[TEXT]
<line: 12> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations set forth in paragraph eight.

[TITLE]
<line: 24> COUNT XVII - NEGLIGENCE

[TITLE]
<line: 26> (Andrew Terrell v. Silver Lake)

[TEXT]
<line: 28> 1. At all times relevant herein, the Defendant, SILVER LAKE, was a duly licensed 
<line: 29> corporation, incorporated in the State of Illinois and doing business as Silver Lake Country Club 
<line: 30> and located at 14700 South 82nd Avenue in the City of Orland Park, County of Cook, and State 
<line: 31> of Illinois. 

[TEXT]
<line: 33> ANSWER:

<line: 37> -25-

[TITLE]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 31      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 26 of 40

[TEXT]
<line: 4> 2. 
<line: 5> Prior to March 18, 2006, the Defendant, SILVER LAKE, hired and employed the 
<line: 6> Defendant PETER DIANGI, as a security guard at the Silver Lake Country Club.  

[TEXT]
<line: 8> ANSWER: 
<line: 9> As the allegations set forth in Count XVII are not directed toward this defendant, 
<line: 10> this defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 12> 3. 
<line: 13> On or about March 18, 2006, the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, was working as a 
<line: 14> security guard and performing his ordinary duties as an employee or agent of the Defendant, 
<line: 15> SILVER LAKE. 

[TEXT]
<line: 17> ANSWER: 
<line: 18> As the allegations set forth in Count XVII are not directed toward this defendant, 
<line: 19> this defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 21> 4. 
<line: 22> On  or about March 18, 2006, the Plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL, and his fiancée 
<line: 23> were married at Queen of Martyrs Church in Evergreen Park. Immediately after the wedding 
<line: 24> ceremony, the plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL, his fiancée, and various other members  
<line: 25> of the wedding guests, including the Plaintiff GEORGE TERRELL, attended a wedding 
<line: 26> reception at Silver Lake Country Club. 

[TEXT]
<line: 28> ANSWER: 
<line: 29> As the allegations set forth in Count XVII are not directed toward this defendant, 
<line: 30> this defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 32> 5. 
<line: 33> During the course of the reception, the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, was 
<line: 34> engaged in his ordinary duties as a security guard and was working in his capacity as employee 
<line: 35> or agent of the Defendant, SILVER LAKE. 

[TEXT]
<line: 37> ANSWER: 
<line: 38> As the allegations set forth in Count XVII are not directed toward this defendant, 
<line: 39> this defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 41> 6. 
<line: 42> At all times relevant herein, the Defendant SILVER LAKE, through its 
<line: 43> employees and agents, including PETER DIANGI, owed a duty of ordinary care to the Plaintiff 

[ABANDON]
<line: 45> -26-

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 31      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 27 of 40

[TEXT]
<line: 4> to hire well-qualified security personnel, and to ensure that the security acted appropriately when 
<line: 5> providing security. 

[TEXT]
<line: 7> ANSWER: 
<line: 8> As the allegations set forth in Count XVII are not directed toward this defendant, 
<line: 9> this defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 11> 7. 
<line: 12> On March 18, 2006, the Defendant, SILVER LAKE, through its employees 
<line: 13> and/or agents, including the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, breached his aforesaid duties to the 
<line: 14> Plaintiff by engaging in one or more of the following negligent acts or omissions: 

[TEXT]
<line: 16> a. 
<line: 17> Negligently failed to properly train the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, as a security 
<line: 18> guard responsible for providing security to patron during social events at SILVER 
<line: 19> LAKE; 
<line: 20> b. 
<line: 21> Negligently failed to adequately supervise the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, 
<line: 22> during the performance of his duties as a security guard; 
<line: 23> c. 
<line: 24> Negligently permitted the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, to work as a security 
<line: 25> guard without sufficient assistance or supervision; 
<line: 26> d. 
<line: 27> Negligently failed to provide adequate security personnel to assist the Defendant,        
<line: 28> PETER DIANGI, in providing security; 
<line: 29> e. 
<line: 30> Negligently hired the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, as a security officer. 

[TEXT]
<line: 32> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count XVII are not directed toward this defendant, 
<line: 33> this defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 35> 8. 
<line: 36> In addition to aforesaid negligent acts and/or omissions, the Defendant SILVER 
<line: 37> LAKE, is vicariously liable for the negligent acts and/or omissions of the Defendant, PETER 
<line: 38> DIANGI, as alleged in Count XIV above. 

[TEXT]
<line: 40> ANSWER: 
<line: 41> As the allegations set forth in Count XVII are not directed toward this defendant, 
<line: 42> this defendant makes no answer to same. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 44> -27-

[TITLE]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 31      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 28 of 40

[TEXT]
<line: 4> 9.

<line: 6> serious physical injuries. Plaintiff also incurred medical expenses and other damages, including 
<line: 7> physical and emotional pain and suffering. 

[TEXT]
<line: 9> ANSWER: 
<line: 10> As the allegations set forth in Count XVII are not directed toward this defendant, 
<line: 11> this defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 13> 10. 
<line: 14> The Plaintiff's injuries were the proximate result of Defendant's aforementioned 
<line: 15> conduct. 

[TEXT]
<line: 17> ANSWER: 
<line: 18> As the allegations set forth in Count XVII are not directed toward this defendant, 
<line: 19> this defendant makes no answer to same

[TITLE]
<line: 8> COUNT XX-WILLFUL & WANTON

[TITLE]
<line: 10> (George Terrell v. Peter Diangi)

[TEXT]
<line: 12> 1. through 13. Plaintiff adopts and realleges Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of the COMMON 
<line: 13> FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS section as and for Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of Count XVI, as 
<line: 14> though fully set forth herein and incorporate the same by reference. 

[TEXT]
<line: 16> ANSWER: Defendant re-adopts and re-alleges in answers to paragraphs 1 through 13, inclusive 
<line: 17> of the common factual allegations section as it answers to paragraph 1 through 13 of Count XX, 
<line: 18> as fully set forth herein and incorporated by referenced. 

[TEXT]
<line: 20> 14. 
<line: 21> Pursuant to 745 ILCS 10/2-202, police officers are liable for injuries resulting 
<line: 22> from their willful and wanton acts or omissions while engaged in the execution or enforcement 
<line: 23> of the law. 

[TEXT]
<line: 25> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph fourteen. 

[TEXT]
<line: 27> 15. 
<line: 28> At all time set forth in Paragraphs 1-13, PETER DIANGI, knew that the Plaintiff, 
<line: 29> GEORGE TERRELL, was legally upon the premises of Silver Lake Country Club. 

[TEXT]
<line: 31>  ANSWER: Defendant admits the allegations contained in paragraph fifteen. 

[TEXT]
<line: 33> 16. 
<line: 34> At all time set forth in Paragraphs 1-13, PETER DIANGI was engaged in the 
<line: 35> execution or enforcement of the law when he grabbed and/or struck the Plaintiff, GEORGE 
<line: 36> TERRELL. More over, PETER DIANGI engaged in willful and wanton conduct during said  

[ABANDON]
<line: 38> -30-

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 31      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 31 of 40

[TEXT]
<line: 4> execution or enforcement of the law by using excessive force in attempting to arrest GEORGE 
<line: 5> TERRELL. 

[TEXT]
<line: 7> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph sixteen. 

[TEXT]
<line: 9> 17. 
<line: 10> As a result of the aforementioned conduct of the Defendants, the Plaintiff 
<line: 11> suffered serious injuries. Plaintiff also incurred medical expenses and other damages, including 
<line: 12> physical and emotional pain and suffering. 

[TEXT]
<line: 14> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph seventeen. 

[TEXT]
<line: 16> 18. 
<line: 17> The Plaintiff's injuries were the proximate result of Defendant's aforementioned 
<line: 18> conduct. 

[TEXT]
<line: 20> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph eighteen. 

[TEXT]
<line: 22> WHEREFORE, the defendant, Peter DiAngi, denies that he is liable in any amount 
<line: 23> whatsoever, to plaintiff, George Terrell, and demands judgment in his favor on all remaining 
<line: 24> pleadings.

<line: 20> GEORGE TERRELL.

[TITLE]
<line: 11> COUNT XXII-42 U.S.C. S1983

[TITLE]
<line: 13> (George Terrell)

[TEXT]
<line: 15> 1. through 13. Plaintiff adopts and realleges Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of the COMMON 
<line: 16> FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS section as and for Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of Count XVIII, as 
<line: 17> though fully set forth herein and incorporate the same by reference. 

[TEXT]
<line: 19> ANSWER: Defendant re-adopts and re-alleges in answers to paragraphs 1 through 13, inclusive 
<line: 20> of the common factual allegations section as it answers to paragraph 1 through 13 of Count IX, 
<line: 21> as fully set forth herein and incorporated by referenced. 

[TEXT]
<line: 23> 13. 
<line: 24> At all time set forth in Paragraphs 1-13, PETER DIANGI, knew that the Plaintiff, 
<line: 25> GEORGE TERRELL, was legally upon the premises of Silver Lake Country Club.  

[TEXT]
<line: 27> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph thirteen.  

[TEXT]
<line: 29> 14. 
<line: 30> At all times set forth in paragraphs 1-13, PETER DIANGI was engaged in the 
<line: 31> execution or enforcement of the law, and was acting under the color of authority when he 
<line: 32> engaged in the conduct alleged herein, and when he arrested the Plaintiff, GEORGE TERRELL. 

[TEXT]
<line: 34> ANSWER:  The allegations set forth in paragraph fourteen are conclusions of law or fact and 
<line: 35> therefore defendant makes no answer to same.  To the extent any factual allegations are set forth 
<line: 36> defendant denies such allegations.  

[ABANDON]
<line: 38> -33-

[TITLE]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 31      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 34 of 40

[TEXT]
<line: 4> 15. 
<line: 5> The conduct engaged in by PETER DIANGI was intentional, malicious, and with 
<line: 6> deliberate indifference to the Plaintiff's rights under the constitution. 

[TEXT]
<line: 8> ANSWER:  Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph fifteen. 

[TEXT]
<line: 10> 16. 
<line: 11> The conduct of the Defendants deprived the Plaintiff of the following rights, 
<line: 12> privileges, and immunities secured to him by the Constitution of the United States. 

[TEXT]
<line: 14> a. 
<line: 15> The right of the Plaintiff to be secure in his person and effects against 
<line: 16> unreasonable search and seizure under the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to 
<line: 17> the Constitution of the United States (Art. IV, U.S. Constitution, Art. XIV, U.S. 
<line: 18> Constitution.); and 
<line: 19> b. 
<line: 20> The right of the Plaintiff not to be deprived of life, liberty, or property without 
<line: 21> due process of law, and the right to the equal protection of the laws, secured by 
<line: 22> the Fourteenth Amendment of the Constitution of the United States (Art. XIV, 
<line: 23> U.S. Constitution). 

[TEXT]
<line: 25> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph sixteen including those 
<line: 26> allegations contained in subparagraphs (a) and (b), inclusive. 

[TEXT]
<line: 28> 17. Prior to March 18, 2006, ORLAND PARK failed to properly train and supervise its 
<line: 29> officers, including, but not limited to PETER DIANGI, regarding proper procedure to be used in 
<line: 30> apprehending a suspect, including the proper use of force. 

[TEXT]
<line: 32> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph seventeen. 

[TEXT]
<line: 34> 18. 
<line: 35> In addition, prior to March 18, 2006, ORLAND PARK failed to discipline its 
<line: 36> officers, including, but not limited to PETER DIANGI, following excessive use of force by 
<line: 37> police such that its officers, including, but not limited to PETER DIANGI, were led to believe 
<line: 38> that the consequences of failing to follow proper procedure in the exercise of force were minimal 
<line: 39> or nonexistent. 

[TEXT]
<line: 41> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph eighteen. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 43> -34-

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 31      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 35 of 40

[TEXT]
<line: 4> 19. 
<line: 5> As a result of the failure of ORLAND PARK to properly train, supervise and 
<line: 6> discipline its officers, including, but not limited to PETER DIANGI, the Plaintiff suffered 
<line: 7> serious injuries. Plaintiff also incurred medical expenses and other damages, including physical 
<line: 8> and emotional pain and suffering. 

[TEXT]
<line: 10> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph nineteen. 

[TEXT]
<line: 12> 20. 
<line: 13> The Plaintiff's injuries were the proximate result of Defendant's aforementioned 
<line: 14> conduct. 

[TEXT]
<line: 16> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph twenty. 

[TEXT]
<line: 18> WHEREFORE, the defendant, Peter DiAngi, denies that he is liable in any amount 
<line: 19> whatsoever, to plaintiff, George Terrell, and demands judgment in his favor on all remaining 
<line: 20> pleadings. 

[TITLE]
<line: 22> AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSES

[TEXT]
<line: 24> NOW COMES the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, and for his Affirmative Defenses to 
<line: 25> Plaintiff's Amended Complaint, without prejudice to the above and foregoing answers, and in the 
<line: 26> alternative, states as follows: 

[TITLE]
<line: 28> FIRST AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE

[TEXT]
<line: 30> The Complaint fails to state a claim upon which relief can be granted. 

[TITLE]
<line: 32> SECOND AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE

[TEXT]
<line: 34> Plaintiffs' claims are barred in whole or in part to the extent that they have failed to 
<line: 35> mitigate, minimize, or avoid any damages they have allegedly sustained. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 37> -35-

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 31      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 36 of 40

[TITLE]
<line: 4> THIRD AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE

[TEXT]
<line: 6> Whatever injuries and damages Plaintiffs may have sustained at the time and place alleged 
<line: 7> in their Complaint were caused by, and arose out of, Plaintiffs' own intentional misconduct, 
<line: 8> including their failure to abide by the instructions of a sworn peace officer. 

[TITLE]
<line: 10> FOURTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE

[TEXT]
<line: 12> Orland Park police officers had probable cause to arrest Plaintiffs. 

[TITLE]
<line: 14> FIFTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE

[TEXT]
<line: 16> At all times relevant to the allegations of Plaintiffs' Amended Complaint, Defendant Peter 
<line: 17> Diangi and other Orland Park police officers acted in good faith and in accordance with the 
<line: 18> Constitution and laws of the United States and the State of Illinois. 

[TITLE]
<line: 20> SIXTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE

[TEXT]
<line: 22> Defendant Peter Diangi acted toward Plaintiffs without malice and without intent to cause 
<line: 23> a deprivation of constitutional rights or other injury to Plaintiffs. 

[TITLE]
<line: 25> SEVENTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE

[TEXT]
<line: 27> Should it be determined that Diangi was functioning as an Orland Park Police officer on 
<line: 28> the date in question, Defendant Peter Diangi was acting pursuant to the policies and general 
<line: 29> orders of the Village of Orland Park Police Department, in conformance with existing statutory 
<line: 30> and case law, thereby affording him with qualified immunity form liability under 42 U.S.C. § 
<line: 31> 1983.  

[TITLE]
<line: 33> EIGHTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE

[TEXT]
<line: 35> Should it be determined that Diangi was functioning as an Orland Park Police officer on 
<line: 36> the date in question, Defendant Peter DiAngi's use of force in the course of arresting Plaintiffs 

[ABANDON]
<line: 38> -36-

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 31      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 37 of 40

[TEXT]
<line: 4> were reasonable, applied in self-defense and/or in the defense of others including bystanders and 
<line: 5> one another. 

[TITLE]
<line: 7> NINTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE

[TEXT]
<line: 9> The plaintiff cannot recover punitive damages against Orland Park. Section 2-102 of the 
<line: 10> Illinois Tort Immunity Act [745 ILCS 10/2-1-2] provides in pertinent part that a local public 
<line: 11> entity such as Orland Park is not liable to pay punitive or exemplary damages in any action 
<line: 12> brought directly or indirectly against it by an injured party or a third party. 

[TITLE]
<line: 14> TENTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE

[TEXT]
<line: 16> Should it be determined that Diangi was functioning as an Orland Park Police officer on 
<line: 17> the date in question, Defendant Peter DiAngi's arrest of Plaintiffs on March 18, 2006 was an act 
<line: 18> in the execution or enforcement of a law; Defendant Peter DiAngi's actions in arresting Plaintiff 
<line: 19> were not willful and wanton conduct; Defendant Peter Diangi is therefore immune from any 
<line: 20> common-law liability to Plaintiffs pursuant to Section 2-202 of the Illinois Local Governmental 
<line: 21> and Governmental Employees Tort Immunity Act, 745 ILCS 10/2-202. 

[TITLE]
<line: 23> ELEVENTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE

[TEXT]
<line: 25> Should it be determined that Diangi was functioning as an Orland Park Police officer on 
<line: 26> the date in question, Defendant Peter DiAngi's arrest of Plaintiffs on March 18, 2006 was an act 
<line: 27> occurring within the scope of his public employment as a police officer, a position involving the 
<line: 28> exercise of discretion and requiring judgment; and Defendant Peter Diangi is therefore immune from 
<line: 29> any common-law liability to Plaintiffs for punitive damages pursuant to Section 2-213 of the 
<line: 30> Illinois Local Governmental and Governmental Employees Tort Immunity Act, 745 ILCS 10/2-
<line: 31> 213. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 33> -37-

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 31      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 38 of 40

[TITLE]
<line: 4> TWELFTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE

[TEXT]
<line: 6> Should it be determined that Diangi was functioning as an Orland Park Police officer on 
<line: 7> the date in question, Defendant Peter DiAngi' s arrest of Plaintiffs on March 18, 2006 was an act 
<line: 8> occurring within the scope of his public employment as a police officer, a position involving the 
<line: 9> determination of policy or the exercise of discretion, and Defendant Peter Diangi is therefore 
<line: 10> immune from any common-law liability to Plaintiffs pursuant to Section 2201 of the Illinois Local 
<line: 11> Governmental and Governmental Employees Tort Immunity Act, 745 ILCS 10/2-201. 

[TEXT]
<line: 13> WHEREFORE, the Defendant Peter Diangi for the complaint to be dismissed with 
<line: 14> prejudice, for the costs of this action, attorneys fees under 42 U.S.C. § 1988 and for such other 
<line: 15> relief as this Court deems just and equitable under the circumstances. 

[TEXT]
<line: 17> DEFENDANT DEMANDS TRIAL BY JURY.  

[TEXT]
<line: 19> LITCHFIELD CAVO LLP  
<line: 20> By: s/ Jeannine S. Gilleran
<line: 21> Attorney for Defendant 
<line: 22> Peter Diangi 

[TEXT]
<line: 24> Jeannine S. Gilleran, Esq.  
<line: 25> LITCHFIELD CAVO, LLP  
<line: 26> 303 West Madison Street  
<line: 27> Suite 300  
<line: 28> Chicago, IL 60606-3300 
<line: 29> (312) 781-6677 

[ABANDON]
<line: 31> -38-

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 31      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 39 of 40

[TEXT]
<line: 4> Jeannine S. Gilleran being first duly sworn on oath deposes and states that he is one of the 
<line: 5> attorneys for defendant,  Peter Diangi and that she has insufficient information to form a belief as to 
<line: 6> the truth or falsity of the allegations contained within paragraphs number 6 of common factual 
<line: 7> allegations and paragraph number 3 of Count XIV of  the Plaintiff's Amended Complaint at Law. 

[TEXT]
<line: 9> By: 
<line: 10> /s/ Jeannine S. Gilleran  

[ABANDON]
<line: 12> -39-

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 31      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 40 of 40

[TITLE]
<line: 4> CERTIFICATE OF SERVICE

[TEXT]
<line: 6> I, the undersigned, being first duly sworn upon oath, depose, and say that I caused to be 
<line: 7> served Defendant Peter Diangi’s Answer to Plaintiff’s Amended Complaint at Law by 
<line: 8> electronically filing the same with the Clerk for the U.S. District Court for the Northern District 
<line: 9> of Illinois, Eastern Division, a copy of which was then forwarded to each attorney of record on 
<line: 10> the 18th day of July,  2008. 

[TITLE]
<line: 12> /s/ Jeannine S. Gilleran 

[TEXT]
<line: 14> Jeannine S. Gilleran  
<line: 15> LITCHFIELD CAVO LLP.  
<line: 16> 303 West Madison Street  
<line: 17> Suite 300 
<line: 18> Chicago, IL 60606 
<line: 19> (312) 781-6677 
<line: 20> (312) 781-6630 fax  

[ABANDON]
<line: 22> -40-
